div1.p: This report recognizes officers whose work was instrumental in the construction of the Panama Canal.

div1.head: Report No. 1022, 63rd Congress: Services of Certain Officers of the Army and Navy, July 27, 1914
div1.p: SERVICES OF CERTAIN OFFICERS OF THE ARMY AND NAVY.

The other engineer members of the commission, with the exception
of Col. Gaillard, under whose supervision the cut was made at Culebra,
and whose untimely death has hereinbefore been referred to, were
Col. W. L. Sibert and Col. H. F. Hodges, of the Army, and Com-
mander H. H. Rousseau of the Navy. The last two named were
special assistants to the chief engineer, Col. Goethals, and in that
capacity rendered valuable services in conferring with the members
who had special supervision of certain portions of the work, as well
as in carrying out the general plan adopted by the commission. In
fact, these men kept at all times in touch with each feature of the
canal work.

Col. William L. Sibert was especially designated to superintend
the construction of the dam across the Chagres River and the three
locks connected therewith on the Atlantic side. Perhaps the construc-
tion of the dam over this river was the most serious part of the entire
work. It is a remarkable coincidence that the late Senator John T.
Morgan, of Alabama, who may very properly be called the father of
the Isthmian Canal, although he did not get the route he preferred,
should have given as his principal objection to the Panama route the
fact that the Chagres River could not be successfully dammed, when,
as a matter of fact, it was dammed under the supervision of this other
Alabamian, Col. Sibert.

The second section of the bill authorizes the President, by and with
the advice and consent of the Senate, in effect, to advance Col.
Goethals and Gen. Gorgas to the rank of major general, the former of
the line and the latter of the Medical Department of the Army, and
provides that no officer belonging to said department or corps shall
be deprived of or prejudiced in his regular promotion.

The third section of the bill increases the number of major generals
of the line by one, and gives to the head of the Medical Department
the rank of major general. It also provides that section 26, of the act
of February 2, 1901, which limits the term of office of the head of the
Medical Department, shall be suspended during the incumbency of
the present head. The effect of this would be to continue Gen. Gorgas
as the medical head of the Army for about six months beyond the
regular term of service and thus prevent the appointment of his suc-
cessor as surgeon general with the rank of brigadier general while
Gen. Gorgas as a major general would still be in active service. This
section also provides that when the officer advanced to the grade of
major general by this act shall be separated from the active list by
retirement or otherwise, such extra office or grade shall cease, and
that the rank of the head of the Medical Department of the Army
thereafter shall be brigadier general. It is further provided that,
upon the retirement of the other officers mentioned in the first section
of this act, to wit, Col. Hodges, Lieut. Col. Sibert, and Commander
Rousseau, the President, by and with the advice and consent of the
Senate, may advance them one grade on the retired list.

That the construction of the Panama Canal is one of the greatest
engineering feats in the history of the world, and that its sanitation
is one of the most remarkable achievements in medical history will
not be denied. It brings the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of this great
country into much closer communication by water, and it will
unquestionably revolutionize, to a large extent, the commerce of the

world upon the high seas. It has been the dream of many centuries.
Spain, Portugal, and Great Britain seriously contemplated it, while
France actually undertook it. But it was American genius that
finally made the dream a realization in fact.

Had this great work been accomplished by any European nation,
the men at the head of it would long since have been knighted, or
some other mark of special recognition and distinction would have
been bestowed upon them. The bill proposes practically the only
way, under our form of government, that their merits can be recog-
nized.

From the days of the Continental Army under George Washington
it has been the practice of this country, in one form or another, to
recognize unusually meritorious service. It is needless to relate the
list. Only a few years ago Congress advanced Peary to the position of
rear admiral in the Navy because the scientific world agreed that he
had discovered the North Pole. The canal will bring practical good by
shortening distances, saving time (and therefore money), and enabling
our Navy to better guard the broad expanse of our Atlantic and
Pacific coasts. A remarkable illustration of its importance is fur-
nished by the record-breaking run around South America made by
our battleship Oregon at the outbreak of the Spanish-American War.

The construction of the Panama Canal, all things considered, is
without precedent in history.

It is respectfully submitted to the House, therefore, that this is a
small but just recognition of American genius, American ability, and
American enterprise.
